speaker: JASON
line: You know what he's capable of. Please! McFarland's going to turn this into a witch hunt. And who do you think he's going to burn at the stake?

speaker: LUCAS
line: Yeah, well you should have thought of that before you published your results.

speaker: JASON
line: No, you should have come to me before you went to McFarland!

speaker: LUCAS
line: I did, Jason, more than once, but you...

speaker: JASON
line: That's bull!

speaker: LUCAS
line: ... you didn't want to hear anything I had to say. You never did.

speaker: JASON
line: So you deliberately went behind my back.

speaker: LUCAS
line: I did exactly... What? What?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: I need to talk to you.

speaker: JASON
line: Excuse us, please.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: That street is dangerous.

speaker: LUCAS
line: Right. Thank you. We'll be fine. Look, I'm not gonna lie about this.

speaker: JASON
line: I'm not asking you to lie.

speaker: LUCAS
line: Then what are you asking me to do?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: I've travelled a long way.

speaker: LUCAS
line: Here, what, you want some money, is that it? Here. Here's a dollar, it's all I have.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: No. No. Listen to me!

speaker: JASON
line: Hey! Hey!...

speaker: OLD MAN
line: I'm trying to save your life.

speaker: JASON
line: ... Hey! Take it easy. Calm down.

speaker: LUCAS
line: Let go!

speaker: SECURITY COP
line: What's the problem here?

speaker: LUCAS
line: This old guy is harassing me.

speaker: JASON
line: No, he's just a little bit agitated.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: No, he's going to die. at exactly 11:46. The bus...

speaker: SECURITY COP
line: We're all gonna die, pop. Come on, let's go sleep it off.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: No!

speaker: SECURITY COP
line: Come with me...

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Jason!

speaker: SECURITY COP
line: ... You'll feel better in the morning.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Don't let him cross the street!

speaker: SECURITY COP
line: All right.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: His papers, he won't see the bus! at 11:46!

speaker: SECURITY COP
line: All right, into the car.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Stop him! No! Jason!

speaker: JASON
line: How did he know my name?

speaker: LUCAS
line: How the hell should I know?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Stop him! You've got to stop him! You don't have to die! You're gonna die! Stop him now! Stop him now!

speaker: JASON
line: Lucas? Wait! Come on, man, give me a chance!

speaker: LUCAS
line: We have got nothing left to talk about.

speaker: JASON
line: Lucas!

speaker: LUCAS
line: Damn it!

speaker: JASON
line: Lucas! Lucas!

speaker: JASON
line: Lucas! No!

speaker: BUS DRIVER
line: What'd you do to him? You pushed him! You pushed him right in front of me! You killed him! What the hell did you do?

speaker: MULDER
line: His name was Lucas Menand, a post-doctoral fellow at MIT. He was a bright and promising researcher, a life dedicated to science cut short by an unfortunate bus accident.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Cause of death was massive head trauma, pronounced on site. But according to the bus driver, it was no accident?

speaker: MULDER
line: He claims that Menand was pushed, by a suspect identified as Jason Nichols , an associate professor of biology as well as Menand's academic advisor.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Says here in the police report they'd been seen arguing earlier that evening, but Jason Nichols has refused to tell police about what.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hmmm... sounds like a motive, doesn't it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Between that and the bus driver's statement, why am I looking at this?

speaker: MULDER
line: Would you like to hear his alibi? I'd do it? who said it would happen! He warned Lucas about the bus! He knew the exact time and place! He tried telling us! He knew my name!

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's his alibi, that some old man came and warned him that his colleague was gonna die?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, he goes on to tell a pretty convincing narrative and to give a rather detailed description of the old man.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What was he wearing, a long black robe and carrying a scythe?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, not when campus security picked him up.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He was arrested?

speaker: MULDER
line: Minutes before the accident, according to Jason Nichols. Packed into a security vehicle, trying to warn Nichols even as he was being hauled away.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Has anybody talked to him?

speaker: MULDER
line: No.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Has anybody talked to the campus security officer?

speaker: MULDER
line: Can't.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why not?

speaker: MULDER
line: He's dead.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Of what?

speaker: BOSTON MEDICAL EXAMINER'S OFFICE, 11
line: 35 AM

speaker: AUTOPSY DOCTOR
line: I haven't been able to make a definitive determination as to cause or time of death. There's been some internal disagreement over how to proceed.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You mean, with the autopsy?

speaker: AUTOPSY DOCTOR
line: Yes... but mostly, rather to cut or to saw. You see why we didn't put him in refrigeration.

speaker: MULDER
line: Have you ever seen a body in such an advanced hypothermic state?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hypothermic? Mulder, this man's an icicle. Did you see this? His ear. It looks like something's been inserted in it.

speaker: AUTOPSY DOCTOR
line: Something has. I took his temperature. I don't know if the reading was accurate, but the thermometer said his body temp was 15 degrees Fahrenheit.

speaker: MULDER
line: Where was he found?

speaker: AUTOPSY DOCTOR
line: On campus, inside his patrol car. Parked just off Adams, with one wheel on the curb. Police also found an empty gin bottle under the driver's seat. Apparently, he had a history. He'd been cited for drinking on duty. You'd assume he'd passed out and froze to death, but the low temperature for last night was 28.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And now, his body temperature is 8 degrees.

speaker: MULDER
line: You mean he's actually getting colder.

speaker: AUTOPSY DOCTOR
line: Like I said, we're a little betwixt and between on how to go forward here. We'd be happy to take your lead on it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I think we're gonna need some time ourselves.

speaker: MULDER
line: So what's your medical opinion, Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, my best guess would be that he's been exposed to some kind of chemical refrigerant, like liquid nitrogen, possibly even ingested it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, you see what happens when you drink and drive?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't know what else to say, Mulder, except that what this doesn't do is add any credence whatsoever to the suspect's alibi that the old man was on the scene.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe we should ask Jason Nichols if he can explain this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What if he can't?

speaker: MULDER
line: We'll just hope that he keeps until Thanksgiving.

speaker: 6TH PRECINCT, 12
line: 22 PM

speaker: LISA
line: This is serious, Jason. This couldn't be more serious. They're talking about charging you with second degree murder. I'll call you as soon as I speak to a lawyer.

speaker: JASON
line: Are you from the FBI?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. Special Agent Mulder. Is that your girlfriend?

speaker: JASON
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: Thanks for seeing me. I know your attorney advised you against it, so I appreciate it.

speaker: JASON
line: I just want to talk to somebody who's going to listen to me. Somebody who's going to tell me they can find that old man.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, people out there looking for him.

speaker: JASON
line: Who? Campus police?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm sure you know that the man who allegedly detained the man you described is now dead.

speaker: JASON
line: So, are they going to try and blame me for that one, too?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, not unless, uh, you're capable of killing a man by flash freezing him.

speaker: JASON
line: What?

speaker: MULDER
line: The security officer who's now in the morgue has a body temperature a little south of Frosty the Snow Man.

speaker: JASON
line: You think that's funny?

speaker: MULDER
line: Do I think what's funny?

speaker: JASON
line: Coming in here and trying to screw with my head!

speaker: MULDER
line: Does this have something to do with you and Lucas Menand?

speaker: JASON
line: Look! He's the one that had been threatening me, OK!

speaker: MULDER
line: He threatened your life?

speaker: JASON
line: My reputation.

speaker: MULDER
line: How'd he do that?

speaker: JASON
line: By saying he would go public with his claim that I'd falsified data on my research paper.

speaker: MULDER
line: Had you?

speaker: JASON
line: No. The theory was sound. If my interpretation of certain data was a little lax, it's because I've been under pressure to produce results. My NSA grant is up for renewal. And Lucas knew how damaging his allegations would be.

speaker: MULDER
line: Was Lucas Menand up for the same grant?

speaker: MULDER
line: And what research would this grant have funded?

speaker: JASON
line: Cryobiology. I study the effects of freezing temperatures on biological systems.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh! Excuse me. Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Has Nichols said anything?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, I'm right in the middle of it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I think we may be filing a second murder charge against him.

speaker: MULDER
line: Security officer?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I found Nichols' right thumbprint on his uniform, and forensics also matched his with the prints they lifted off the interior of the patrol car. I think the old man in this story is gonna be Jason Nichols serving 25 to life in a federal prison.

speaker: HOTEL JAMES MONROE, 6
line: 05 PM

speaker: DESK CLERK
line: I'm sorry, sir, there's nothing more we can do.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: My name is Yonechi.

speaker: DESK CLERK
line: Yes sir, you've told me. But I'm not finding a reservation under that name.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: But this is where I am supposed to stay.

speaker: DESK CLERK
line: I'm sorry, sir. I don't know what else to tell you.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Dr. Yonechi?

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: Yes?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: There's been a misunderstanding. I'm afraid my assistant made a reservation at the wrong hotel, so I came here myself to make sure you, uh, you got a room. It's, uh, it's a good room with a view of the river.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: You are not, uh, Dr. Nichols?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: He apologizes. He was not able to be here to meet you yourself, so he asked me to come in his place.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: Excuse me, but who are you?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: A great admirer of your work.

speaker: BELLMAN
line: Here we go, sir.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: Thank you.

speaker: BELLMAN
line: After you, sir.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: No. Go ahead.

speaker: BELLMAN
line: If you need anything, just give us a call. Here you are, sir. Have a good evening, sir.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: Are you sick?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: No, no, I'm fine. Thank you.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: May I get you some water?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: If it's no trouble.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: Please, come in.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: The, uh, mixup with the reservation? It was actually my fault.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: Your fault?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: But I owe you so much.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: For what?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Your contribution to my work. Vitrification. You were the one who solved the problem.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: Me? No, not yet. No one has solved vitrification.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Oh, yes, Yonni. You found a way to substitute water with a sugar - trehalose. Your paper... it changed everything.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: I am sorry, Yonni. But this is the only way.

speaker: DR. YONECHI
line: Aaaauuuuggggghhhhh!

speaker: MULDER
line: I just spoke with the bellman who brought up the luggage.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What did he say?

speaker: MULDER
line: The iceman cometh. Dr. Yonechi was accompanied by a man in his seventies. It's a description confirmed by the desk clerk. They're working with a composite artist on a sketch right now.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sounds like Jason Nichols has an accomplice.

speaker: MULDER
line: It sounds like that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: More than that, Mulder, it makes sense. Science is a high-stakes game. Jason Nichols is trying to eliminate his competitors and he's succeeding.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, but what if he's being set up?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He's a cryobiologist. He freezes things for a living. How many people can do that?

speaker: MULDER
line: Just about anybody who's up for that grant money could.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I want to show you something. This is what's called a nuclear magnetic resonance spectra. Dr. Yonechi had a spot of blood on the heel of his hand - a pin prick, something that might have been caused by a small gauge hypodermic needle. Now, I found the same thing on the security officer. This is the analysis.

speaker: MULDER
line: What is it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, no one at the lab would even hazard a guess, but we think it's some kind of unidentifiable chemical compound.

speaker: MULDER
line: A lethal injection?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You'll have to ask Jason Nichols.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, there's somebody I want to talk to first.

speaker: BIO-MEDICAL RESEARCH FACILITY, 10
line: 22 PM

speaker: MULDER
line: Lisa Ianelli? I'm sorry, I didn't mean to startle you.

speaker: LISA
line: No, I was working. Sometimes you just get lost in it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. You may remember me from this afternoon. I spoke with Jason.

speaker: LISA
line: From the FBI.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm Agent Scully. May I show you something?

speaker: LISA
line: Uh-huh. Where'd you get this?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You recognize it? Lisa, you can tell us now or we can subpoena your testimony in court. Either way, we'll find out what you know about it.

speaker: LISA
line: It's a kind of catalyst.

speaker: SCULLY
line: A catalyst for what?

speaker: LISA
line: A self-sustaining endothermic reaction. It's a rapid freezing agent - something Jason's been engineering for years. See, when a cell freezes, its moisture forms into ice crystals, which literally grind up the cell from the inside out. But extreme rapid freezing causes a smoother, glass-like structure to form instead. So the cell can survive being thawed. At least, according to Jason's theory.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This compound... has Jason actually tested it yet?

speaker: LISA
line: He hasn't tested it yet because it doesn't exist - except in the computer. So far the work's been limited to generating virtual chemicals - like this. In fact, what we're looking at here is a version of the catalyst you brought me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is it possible that he could have synthesized the compound without you knowing about it?

speaker: LISA
line: Not even remotely. The technology to engineer something like that is still five, ten years away - minimum.

speaker: MULDER
line: Not any more, apparently.

speaker: LISA
line: What are you talking about?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Traces of the compound were detected in a man who was found dead last night - frozen solid.

speaker: LISA
line: Then there must be some kind of mistake.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And a, uh, a Dr. Yonechi was also found frozen to death.

speaker: LISA
line: What?

speaker: MULDER
line: In his heated hotel room.

speaker: LISA
line: When was this?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Just over two hours ago. Why is that relevant?

speaker: LISA
line: Because he may not be dead.

speaker: LISA
line: What's his temp?

speaker: DOCTOR
line: His core temperature is up to 97.

speaker: LISA
line: OK. Let's take him out.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: And then what?

speaker: LISA
line: We've got to try to resuscitate him. Let's go.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: All right, on my count... one... two... three.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This isn't gonna work.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why not?

speaker: SCULLY
line: His body temperature was 8 degrees. The lowest reported body temperature ever survived by a human being was 70.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, if he's already dead, then he's got nothing to lose.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: OK, we're hooked up. All right, Dr. Ianelli, we're gonna want to start with 300 joules and an amp of epi.

speaker: TECHNICIAN 1
line: Charging.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Clear?

speaker: TECHNICIAN 1
line: Clear.

speaker: TECHNICIAN 2
line: Still no pulse.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Go to 360. Clear?

speaker: TECHNICIAN 1
line: Clear.

speaker: TECHNICIAN 2
line: No response.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Give him another amp of intracardial epi and atropine 1 milligram. Try again at 360. Clear?

speaker: TECHNICIAN 1
line: Clear.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: He's got a rhythm.

speaker: LISA
line: Dr. Yonechi, you're in a prototype frostbite bay in Cambridge, Mass. You've been unconscious for almost 12 hours. Dr. Yonechi? My name is Lisa Ianelli.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Don't try and talk right now. We've inserted a tube down your throat to help you breathe. Try not to fight the machine. Let it breathe for you.

speaker: LISA
line: Something's wrong.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, look at his temperature.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh my God. He's on fire. He's having febrile siezures.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: This can't be right. He's burning up. Hold him down! Hold him down!

speaker: TECHNICIAN
line: Oh my God! Oh my God!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Lisa, what happened? What, what could have happened to create such a violent cellular reaction?

speaker: LISA
line: I don't know. All I can think is the compound used to freeze him must have been unstable.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So raising his body temperature may have catalyzed an opposite reaction, heating him internally.

speaker: LISA
line: Uh-huh. I question now if we should have removed him from the tub. I think we might have saved him.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think the real question is how somebody could have had access to a compound that doesn't exist.

speaker: LISA
line: I'm sorry. I need to talk to Jason.

speaker: LISA
line: Who are you? I said, who are you? What do you want? Why are you following me?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Unless I'm mistaken, you're the one following me.

speaker: LISA
line: I saw you outside.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: I'm afraid you're confusing me with someone else.

speaker: LISA
line: You're the man Jason saw, aren't you? You killed Lucas Menand and Dr. Yonechi.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: And I can kill you.

speaker: LISA
line: Let go of me.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: I came here to kill you.

speaker: LISA
line: Who are you?

speaker: MULDER
line: You say he followed you off the bus?

speaker: LISA
line: Yes. I noticed him just before my stop.

speaker: MULDER
line: And you were on your way to see Jason?

speaker: LISA
line: Yes. I confronted him inside the library. He followed me in there. And then he grabbed me - hurt my arm.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What did he say?

speaker: LISA
line: That he could kill me. That that's why he was following me. He threatened me with some kind of medical instrument.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But he just let you go? Lisa, if you're leaving anything out, if you're hedging the truth, you could be held accountable if Jason committed a crime.

speaker: LISA
line: It wasn't Jason. It was me. I falsified the data to get the grant. Jason's covering for me. He's sitting in jail because of me.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's what he can't tell anyone?

speaker: SCULLY
line: But there are people who could have figured it out - Lucas Menand, Dr. Yonechi. These people are now dead.

speaker: LISA
line: No, it's not what you think.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know who this old man is, don't you?

speaker: LISA
line: I don't, I swear to you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But Jason does. He has to, because this man is doing what Jason can't, he's protecting your secret.

speaker: LISA
line: He swore to me he would never confess it to a soul.

speaker: SCULLY
line: If he'd lie for you, what makes you think he wouldn't lie to you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully? It doesn't really makes sense, Scully. Why would he threaten her if he's the one who's protecting her secret.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Because it's not just her secret. It's Jason's secret, too, and the old man is protecting Jason.

speaker: MULDER
line: With a medical instrument?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I suppose it is an unlikely choice as a murder weapon.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well what if it's not a murder weapon? I'm just speculating, but what if it was designed for some other purpose?

speaker: POLICEMAN
line: Agent Mulder? We've been canvassing the area. Hotel manager from a couple of blocks away thinks he's made your guy. It's on McKinney Street. Hotel's called The Lighthouse.

speaker: MULDER
line: Tell the unit to keep watch until we get there. Make sure she gets home safely.

speaker: MULDER
line: Federal agents, sir, open the door.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Are you sure this is the room?

speaker: MULDER
line: Hotel manager says he's been living here for five days.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm not sure if 'living' is a word I'd use on this place.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yonechi's flight information was taken down on this pad.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, look at this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: When was this taken?

speaker: MULDER
line: And what's the occasion?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's a celebration, but of what?

speaker: MULDER
line: Or something that never happened.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What? Mulder, this is a photograph. It is a documented moment in time.

speaker: MULDER
line: In a future that somebody is trying like hell to prevent from happening.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What?

speaker: MULDER
line: Think about it, Scully. If Lucas Menand never gets hit by the bus, his complaint gets heard before the grant committee. Jason Nichols loses his funding and he never gets to collaborate on his research with Dr. Yonechi. Therefore, this photograph never gets taken because this celebration never happens.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And if your sister is your aunt and your mother marries your uncle, you'd be your own grandpa.

speaker: MULDER
line: The old man couldn't save Lucas Menand, so he had to kill Dr. Yonechi.

speaker: SCULLY
line: OK, so this photo that was never taken, when was it never taken.

speaker: MULDER
line: At least five years in the future, when they first synthesized the freezing compound successfully. Let's take the stairs.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, the compound already exists. We have physical evidence.

speaker: MULDER
line: Only because the old man brought it back with him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Back from where?

speaker: MULDER
line: From when may be the real question.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're seriously suggesting that this old man is back from the future?

speaker: MULDER
line: Unless you have a better explanation for how he knew exactly when and how Lucas Menand was gonna be killed, why Jason Nichol's fingerprints are inside that patrol car, and how he knew Lisa Ianelli's secret.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So what you're saying here is the old man is...

speaker: MULDER
line: Jason Nichols. Although common sense may rule out the possibility of time travel, the laws of quantum physics certainly do not. In case you forgot, that's from your graduate thesis. You were a lot more open-minded when you were a youngster.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I know what I wrote, Mulder. I also know that the laws of physics would permit the theoretical possibility of time travel, but the limits of human endurance would prevent such a trip from ever happening.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, there's one sure to prove that theoretical possiblity.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How?

speaker: MULDER
line: Show this photograph to Lisa Ianelli and ask her if it was ever taken.

speaker: LISA
line: Jason? I don't understand. How is this possible?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Because you made it possible. It was you.

speaker: LISA
line: How? I need to know.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Thirty years ago - ten years from now - you'll be at a conference in Zurich. You'll meet a man named McGuane who's just discovered the first evidence of tachyons - subatomic particles that can travel faster than the speed of light and go back in time - but only for a few seconds and only at a temperature of absolute zero. But from that, and from your correspondence with McGuane, you'll have an idea. A revelation.

speaker: LISA
line: What revelation?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: One so remarkable, it would change the course of history.

speaker: LISA
line: Then why did you... you said you came back to kill me.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: But I couldn't do it.

speaker: LISA
line: You're cold. Jason...

speaker: OLD MAN
line: Yes.

speaker: LISA
line: Uhhh!

speaker: CLERK
line: Sign here.

speaker: MULDER
line: Jason.

speaker: JASON
line: What are you doing here?

speaker: MULDER
line: I arranged for your bail.

speaker: JASON
line: I assumed it was Lisa.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, that's why I'm here. Something's happened to her.

speaker: JASON
line: What are you talking about.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think it's something you should see for yourself. She's at the Medical Research Facility.

speaker: JASON
line: Was it the old man?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes.

speaker: JASON
line: Why haven't you found him yet? Who the hell is he?

speaker: MULDER
line: Look, Jason, I don't expect you to get your mind around this completely right now...

speaker: JASON
line: What?

speaker: MULDER
line: The man we're looking for - the old man - he's you.

speaker: MULDER
line: If that photo is indicative of a pattern, you may be his next target. It puts a whole new spin on being your own worst enemy, huh?

speaker: JASON
line: Except that I've never met Dr. Yonechi and neither has Lisa. So this must have been altered somehow.

speaker: MULDER
line: Not according to the photo specialist that I had examine it. As far as she can tell, it's the real McCoy.

speaker: JASON
line: Then maybe you should get a second opinion, because I'm not buying your story.

speaker: MULDER
line: Jason, it's your story.

speaker: JASON
line: It's science fiction.

speaker: MULDER
line: So was your rapid freezing agent until two days ago. Now why don't you just consider the evidence as a scientist. How could the old man come to possess a compound that you yourself admit doesn't exist?

speaker: JASON
line: Whoever he is, why would he be trying to prevent my compound from being developed?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not sure of that yet.

speaker: JASON
line: But you have a theory.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I think it has something to do with the practical application of your compound, though I don't know what that is yet.

speaker: JASON
line: Involving time travel.

speaker: MULDER
line: Physicists like Stephen Hawking have hypothesized the existence of wormholes and closed time loops, actual portals through which matter can travel backward through time. Although, phenomena like extreme heat and gravity would render the trip lethal for any organism.

speaker: JASON
line: So you're saying the properties of my compound will make it possible?

speaker: MULDER
line: Eventually, yes, that's what I'm saying.

speaker: JASON
line: But why stop time travel?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's what I'm hoping the old man can tell us.

speaker: JASON
line: Agent Mulder, if any of this is true... then what happened to Lisa... is really my fault.

speaker: JASON
line: Going up to the cryo lab.

speaker: SECURITY GUARD
line: Mmmm, hmmm.

speaker: SECURITY GUARD
line: Hey, wait a sec. Are you Dr. Jason Nichols?

speaker: JASON
line: That's right.

speaker: SECURITY GUARD
line: Then something's wrong. It says you're already in the building.

speaker: MULDER
line: Listen to me, Jason. I need you to get to Scully and tell her that he's here. She's in the frostbite bay with Lisa. Can you do that? All right.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Clear?

speaker: NURSE 1
line: Clear.

speaker: SECURITY GUARD
line: Let's give her another amp of epinephrine and we'll go again at 360.

speaker: NURSE 1
line: Charging.

speaker: NURSE 2
line: Epi given.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Clear?

speaker: NURSE 3
line: Everybody clear.

speaker: NURSE 1
line: Increase of dmso.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: We have a rhythm.

speaker: NURSE 1
line: Pulse.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Now what?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Get her back in the tub. Now.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: All right, let's disconnect and get her back in, right away.

speaker: NURSE 3
line: Here we go.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Let's go.

speaker: NURSE 1
line: All right, here we go.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Easy...

speaker: SCULLY
line: How hot's the reading now?

speaker: RESEARCH ASSISTANT
line: Is there a problem?

speaker: MULDER
line: Has anybody been through here in the last hour?

speaker: RESEARCH ASSISTANT
line: Well, there was a maintenance guy who fixed the fan, but, other than that, it's just been me.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, I'm looking for an older man, a man in his mid-seventies maybe.

speaker: RESEARCH ASSISTANT
line: No, I haven't seen anybody like that. Why, does this have something to do with Dr. Nichols?

speaker: MULDER
line: Do you work with him?

speaker: RESEARCH ASSISTANT
line: I'm one of his research assistants.

speaker: MULDER
line: You have access to his files.

speaker: RESEARCH ASSISTANT
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'd like to pull up some information about his rapid freezing compound.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We've resuscitated her, Mulder. Her body temperature is still high but it seems to have stabilized.

speaker: MULDER
line: Did Jason help?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He's not here.

speaker: MULDER
line: All right, he should have been there five minutes ago, Scully.

speaker: RESEARCH ASSISTANT
line: What is this?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where are you?

speaker: RESEARCH ASSISTANT
line: This is crazy.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Let me get back to you, Scully. What?

speaker: RESEARCH ASSISTANT
line: It's Dr. Nichols' files. They're totally whacked.

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you mean, "whacked"?

speaker: RESEARCH ASSISTANT
line: His data... it's gone. It's like somebody's completely erased it from the mainframe.

speaker: JASON
line: I knew I'd find you here. I figured this is where I'd go to stop myself.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: I don't have much time. Please, let me finish.

speaker: JASON
line: Let you finish destroying my work?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: It's my work, too.

speaker: JASON
line: I want her back!

speaker: OLD MAN
line: I know.

speaker: JASON
line: Then tell me how to go back so I can save her. Please.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: I don't expect you to understand.

speaker: JASON
line: Understand what?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: What she created. What you - we - helped to create. A world without history, without hope. Where anyone can know everything that will ever happen. I've seen that world.

speaker: JASON
line: Tell me how to go back.

speaker: OLD MAN
line: I can't

speaker: JASON
line: You will! Tell me!

speaker: OLD MAN
line: No, Jason! Try to understand!

speaker: MULDER
line: Jason!

speaker: JASON
line: Tell me how to go back so I can save her!

speaker: MULDER
line: Jason! She's alive, Lisa's alive! Don't hurt him! If you hurt him, we'll never know the truth! Open the door.

speaker: JASON
line: She's ok?

speaker: OLD MAN
line: It's better that we never were.

speaker: JASON
line: No!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Lisa? It's Dana Scully, can you hear me? You're going to be fine. We knew to keep you submerged in order to maintain your body temperature. After what happened to Dr. Yonechi, your theory about the compound's instability, well, you proved it yourself.

speaker: LISA
line: He said, he said he was Jason.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The old man? Look, there's been some incongruous evidence. I've had difficulty explaining myself.

speaker: LISA
line: It was him, Agent Scully. It was Jason.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Lisa, Jason's dead. There was a fire in the mainframe room. I'm sorry. I'll see you at the hospital.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You find the second corpse?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, and I'm not holding out much hope that they will, either.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We should put out an APB on the old man.

speaker: MULDER
line: They won't find him. I know what I saw, Scully, and I know what I believe happened.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Even if it can never be proven?

speaker: MULDER
line: Never? Never is a very long time, Scully, you said that yourself. "Although multidimensionality suggests infinite outcomes in an infinite number of universes, each universe can produce only one outcome."

speaker: SCULLY
line: I was 23 when I wrote that.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, but I take that to mean that you were suggesting that the future can't be altered. Which means that the elder Jason Nichols' attempts to stop his own research will fail, and that eventually his compound, and time travel, will be discovered.
